nirbvinnānāṃ jñānayogo'nvāsinām ihakarmasu | teṣyanirbviṇa cittānāṃ, karmayogaśca kāmināṃ ||

For those who are detached/dispassionate, the yoga of knowledge (jñāna yoga) is prescribed. For those engaged in worldly actions here, who have minds not yet detached, the yoga of action (karma yoga) is for the desirous.
c4a86e1f3fd7:
# Passage

वृत्तस्य षड्भुजं । ॐ नमो षोढ़ारूपं । अउम॰ ৺नमषडिन्द्रिय षड्र स षडङ्गादिस्वरूपं ।

vṛttasya ṣaḍbhujaṃ | oṃ namo ṣoḍhārūpaṃ | auṃ ৺namaṣaḍindriya ṣaḍrasa ṣaḍaṅgādisvarūpaṃ

The six-sided figure of the circle. Om Namo in sixteen-fold form. A-U-M bindu namo representing the six senses, six tastes, six limbs, and such forms.

oṃ vṛttasyāṣṭabhujaṃ | oṃ namoyuktaṃ auoṃ ৺ namaḥ | aṣṭa buddhīndriya tathā īśvarāṣṭamūrtirūpaṃ

The eight-sided figure of the Om-circle. Om Namo combined with A-U-O-M bindu namo. Representing the eight cognitive senses and also Īśvara's eight-fold form (aṣṭa-mūrti).

# Passage

तदेतदक्षरं ब्रह्मसप्राणस्तदबाङ्गनः ।तदेतत् सत्यं तदमृतं तद्वोद्धव्यं सौम्यबिद्धि ॥तदेतत् सर्ब्बाश्रयः आयम्य तद्भाब गतेन चेतसा ।लक्ष्यं तदेबाक्षरं सौम्य बिद्धि ॥तद्विज्ञानेन परिपश्यन्ति धीराः ।आनन्द रूपममृतं यद्बिभाति ॥तत् शुभ्रं तद् ज्योतिषां ज्योतिस्तदात्मबिदो बिदुः ।तमेवभान्तमनुभाति सर्ब्बं, तस्य भाषा सर्ब्बमिदम्बिभाति ॥

tadetadakṣaraṃ brahmasaprāṇastadabāṅganaḥ | tadetat satyaṃ tadamṛtaṃ tadvoddhavyaṃ saumyaviddhi || tadetat sarbvāśrayaḥ āyamya tadbhāba gatena cetasā | lakṣyaṃ tadevākṣaraṃ saumya viddhi || tadvijñānena paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ | ānanda rūpamamṛtaṃ yadbibhāti || tat śubhraṃ tad jyotiṣāṃ jyotistad ātmavido viduḥ | tamevabhāntamanubhāti sarbaṃ, tasya bhāṣā sarbbamidambibhāti ||

That is the imperishable syllable, Brahman with the vital breath, that which has no parts. That is Truth, that is Immortality, that is to be known - know this, O gentle one. That is the support of all - having restrained it, with consciousness absorbed in that state, that imperishable should be known as the goal, O gentle one.

Through knowledge of That, the wise perceive it clearly. That which shines as the form of bliss, immortal. That is pure, that is the light of lights, that the knowers of Self know. By that alone shining does everything shine; through its radiance all this shines forth.
82eedae311a2:
# Passage

सदेवइदमग्र आसीत्, एकमेवाद्वितीयं ।तदाह एकेआहुः असदेवइदमग्रमासीत् एकमेवाद्वितीयं ॥तस्मादसतः सज्जायेत ।कुतस्तुखलु स्यादिति ।  कथमसतः सज्जायेत इति ॥तत्त्वेवइदमग्रआसीत्, एकमेवाद्वितीयं ॥तदैक्षत वहुस्यां प्रजायेय ।

sadevaidamagra āsīt, ekamevādvitīyaṃ | tadāha ekeāhuḥ asadevaidamagramāsīt ekamevādvitīyaṃ || tasmādasataḥ sajjāyeta | kutastukhalu syāditi | kathamasataḥ sajjāyeta iti || tattvevaidamagrāsīt, ekamevādvitīyaṃ || tadaikṣata vahusyāṃ prajāyeya |

In the beginning, Being (sat) alone existed, one without a second. About this, some say: "In the beginning, Non-being (asat) alone existed, one without a second." From that Non-being, Being would have been born. But how could this be? How could Being be born from Non-being? Therefore, in truth, in the beginning Being alone existed, one without a second. That Being contemplated: "May I become many, may I procreate."

# Passage

चतुर्वर्ग प्रदा बिद्या चतुर्बिन्द्वात्मिकासदा । आद्यन्ते प्रणवंदत्वा
गायत्रीं प्रजपेद्दिज । बामाधर्म्म प्रदा बिन्दुर्ज्येष्ठा अर्थ प्रदा तथा । रौद्रीकाम प्रदाबिन्दुः श्रीबिन्दुः मोक्षदायिनी ॥ महेश्वर
बदनं बिन्दुः श्रीबिष्णोः हृदयंतथा ॥ मोक्षदाताच श्रीबिन्दुः चतुर्बिन्दु बिनिर्णयः ॥

caturvarga pradā bidyā caturbindvātmikāsadā | ādyante praṇavaṃdatvā
gāyatrīṃ prajapeddija | vāmadharmma pradā bindurjyeṣṭhā artha pradā tathā | raudrīkāma pradābinduḥ śrībinduḥ mokṣadāyinī || maheśvara
vadanaṃ binduḥ śrībiṣṇoḥ hṛdayaṃtathā || mokṣadātāca śrībinduḥ caturbindu binirṇayaḥ ||

The vidya (sacred knowledge) that grants the four goals (purushartha) is always composed of four bindus (dots/points). Having placed pranava (OM) at the beginning and end, the twice-born should recite the Gayatri. The Vama bindu grants dharma, the Jyeshtha grants artha (wealth), the Raudri bindu grants kama (desire), and the Shri bindu bestows moksha (liberation). The bindu is the face of Maheshvara and also the heart of Shri Vishnu. The Shri bindu is the giver of liberation—thus is the determination of the four bindus.

dīpyatom jyotiḥ | prakāśaṇājjyotiḥ | praṇavākhya praṇetāramarūpo bigatanidro bijaro bimṛtyurbiśoko bhavatītyevaṃ hyāha | maitrī upa
6 .25 tathā | yadamusminnāditye'thaṃsomo'gnau vidyuti bibhātyathakhalvenaṃ dṛṣṭvā mṛtatvaṃ gacchatītyāha | 6 .25 |

The shining OM is light. Light comes from illumination. It says: "One who leads, called pranava, becomes formless, free from sleep, ageless, deathless, and sorrowless." Maitri Upanishad 6.25. Likewise, it says: "When that which shines in the sun, moon, fire, and lightning is seen, one attains immortality." 6.25.

यस्मादुच्चरितमात्र एब सर्ब्बं शरीरं बिद्योतयति ।
तस्मादोमित्यनेनैता उपासीतापरिमितं तेजः । मैत्री उप ७ ।११ ।

yasmāduccāritamātra eva sarvvaṃ śarīraṃ vidyotayati |
tasmādomityanenaitā upāsītāparimitaṃ tejaḥ | maitrī upa 7 .11 |

Because its mere utterance illuminates the entire body, therefore one should meditate on this unlimited radiance through OM. Maitri Upanishad 7.11.

आपो ज्योतिरसोऽमृतं
ब्रह्मभूर्भुबःस्वरोम् । मैत्री ६ ।३५ । दीप्यतोमापः । ओङ्कारोऽनुज्ञापनादाप्यायनादापः । इति तट्टीका ।

āpo jyotiraso'mṛtaṃ
brahmabhūrbhuvaḥsvarom | maitrī 6 .35 | dīpyatomāpaḥ | oṅkāro'nujñāpanādāpyāyanādāpaḥ | iti taṭṭīkā |

Water, light, nectar (essence), the immortal, Brahman, bhūr bhuvaḥ svaḥ, OM. Maitri 6.35. The shining OM is water. Omkara is water because of permission and nourishment. Thus says the commentary.

ॐ रसोबैतत् । रसः कर्म्म
परिपाक निवृत्तत्वात् आदित्यस्य रसतं? सर्ब्ब कर्म्म फलाश्रय इत्यर्थः ।

oṃ rasovaitat | rasaḥ karmma
paripāka nivṛtttatvāt ādityasya rasataṃ? sarvva karmma phalāśraya ityarthaḥ |

OM is the essence. The essence is the result of karma because of the sun's completion and cessation. The meaning is: the sun is the repository of all fruits of action.

ब्रह्मनस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः । ब्राह्मणश्चैब बेदाश्च यज्ञाश्चबिहिताः पुरा । बैदिके कर्म्मणि तेषां प्रथमतो निर्द्देशः । इति तां बाचस्पतिः ।

oṃ tatsaditi nirdeśo
brahmamastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇaścaiva vedāśca yajñāścavihitāḥ purā | vaidike karmmaṇi teṣāṃ prathamato nirdeśaḥ | iti tāṃ vācaspatiḥ |

OM TAT SAT—this threefold designation of Brahman is remembered. Brahmins, Vedas, and sacrifices were ordained in ancient times. In Vedic rituals, their designation comes first. Thus says Vacaspati.

aeaf4ec64027:
# Passage

तथा तत् प्रयोगकल्पः । प्राणायामः प्रत्याहारोध्यानंधारणातर्कः समाधिः । षड्वर्गो इत्युच्यते ।—

       अनेन यदा पश्यन् पश्यति रुक्भवर्णं कर्त्तारमीशं पुरुषं ब्रह्मयोनिं ।
       तदाबिद्बान् पुण्य पापे विहाय परेऽव्यये सर्ब्बमेकी करोतीत्येबं ह्याह ।
    यथा पर्ब्बत मादीप्त माश्रयन्ति मृगद्विजाः । तद्वद्ब्रह्मविदो दोषानाश्रयन्ति कदाचन ॥१८

    अथान्यत्राप्युक्तं  । यदावैवहिर्विद्वान् मनोनियम्य इन्द्रियार्थांश्च प्राणोनिवेशयित्वा
    निःसङ्कल्पस्ततस्तिष्ठेत् । अप्राणादिह यस्मात् सम्भूतः प्राणसंज्ञको जीवस्तस्मात्
    प्राणोवैतुर्याख्ये धारयेत् । अचित्तं चित्तमध्यस्तमचिन्त्यं गुह्यमुत्तममं ।
    तत्र चित्तं निधायेत तच्च लिङ्गं निराश्रयं ॥

tathā tat prayogakalpaḥ | prāṇāyāmaḥ pratyāhārodhyānaṃdhāraṇātarkaḥ samādhiḥ | ṣaḍvargo ityucyate |—

       anena yadā paśyan paśyati rukbhavarṇaṃ karttāramīśaṃ puruṣaṃ brahmayoniṃ |
       tadābidvān puṇya pāpe vihāya pare'vyaye sarbbamekī karotītyevaṃ hyāha |
    yathā parbata madīpta māśrayanti mṛgadvijāḥ | tadvadbrahmavido doṣānāśrayanti kadācana ||18

    athānyatrāpyuktaṃ  | yadāvaivahirvidvān manoniyamya indriyārthāṃśca prāṇoniveśayitvā
    niḥsaṅkalpastatastiṣṭhet | aprāṇādiha yasmāt sambhūtaḥ prāṇasaṃjñako jīvastasmāt
    prāṇovaituryākhye dhārayet | acittaṃ cittamadhyastamacittyaṃ guhyamuttamamaṃ |
    tatra cittaṃ nidhāyeta tacca liṅgaṃ nirāśrayaṃ ||

Thus are the methods of practice. Pranayama (breath control), pratyahara (withdrawal of senses), dhyana (meditation), dharana (concentration), tarka (reasoning), and samadhi (absorption)—these are called the six limbs.

When through this one sees the golden-hued Creator, the Lord, the Purusha, the source of Brahman, then the knower, abandoning merit and sin, makes everything one in the supreme imperishable. Thus it is said:

"As deer and birds take refuge in a burning mountain, so the knower of Brahman never takes refuge in defects." (18)

And it is also said elsewhere: When the wise one, having controlled the mind and the sense objects, and having established the prana (life-force), then stands free from concepts; because the jiva (individual soul) called prana is born from the breathless state, therefore one should hold the prana in that state called turiya (the fourth state). The mind is beyond mind, inconceivable, secret, and supreme. There one should place the mind, and that subtle mark is without support.

ॐवृत्तस्य सप्तभुजं । अउम॰ ৺ नमःयुक्तं  । प्रज्ञादि आत्मारूपं । सप्तभुवनमयविराजरूपं ।
   सप्त ग्रह सप्त द्वीप सप्त समुद्रञ्च ।

oṃvṛttasya saptabhujaṃ | auṃa॰ ৺ namaḥyuktaṃ  | prajñādi ātmārūpaṃ | saptabhuvanamayavirājarūpaṃ |
   sapta graha sapta dvīpa sapta samudraṃñca |

The seven arms of the OM circle. Combined with A-U-M-nada-bindu-namaḥ. The form of the Self beginning with consciousness (prajña). The form of Viraj consisting of the seven worlds. And the seven planets, seven islands, and seven oceans.
a81d7307de0d:
# Passage

ॐ वृत्तस्य नव भुजं । त्रिभुजस्यत्रिभक्तभुजत्रयं । ओन्नमो शान्ति युक्तं  । अउओम॰ ৺ नमः शान्ति ।
   आत्मनः नवधारूपाणि । तथाजीवदेहस्य नवद्वारानिच । आत्मनः नव रूपाणि यथा—
   अ-जाग्रत् बैश्वानरः । उ-स्वप्नजतैजनः । म-सुसुप्त प्रज्ञा । ओ-तुरीयपरात्पर व्रह्म ।
   ৺ नाद समष्टि सूत्रात्मा । ॰ विन्दुव्यष्टि हिरण्य गर्भः । नमः स्थूलविश्वः । शक्ति विश्वरूपः ।
   शान्तिविराजरूपं । सर्ब्बमोङ्कारस्य नव रेखभिः दर्शितं । यथा ॐ

oṃ vṛttasya nava bhujaṃ | tribhujasyatribhaktabhujatrāyaṃ | onnamo śānti yuktaṃ  | auoṃa॰ ৺ namaḥ śānti |
   ātmanaḥ navadhārūpāṇi | tathājīvadehasya navadvārānici | ātmanaḥ nava rūpāṇi yathā—
   a-jāgrat vaiśvānaraḥ | u-svapnajataijanaḥ | m-susupta prajñā | o-turīyaparātpara vrahma |
   ৺ nāda samaṣṭi sūtrātmā | ॰ vinduvyaṣṭi hiraṇya garbhaḥ | namaḥ sthūlaviśvaḥ | śakti viśvarūpaḥ |
   śāntavirājarūpaṃ | sarbbamoṅkārasya nava rekhabhiḥ darśitaṃ | yathā oṃ

The nine arms of the OM circle. The three arms of the triangle divided into three sections. Combined with OM-namaḥ-śānti. A-U-O-M-nada-bindu-namaḥ-śānti. The nine forms of the Self, and likewise the nine doors of the living body. The nine forms of the Self are as follows:

A - Waking state, Vaishvanara. U - Dream state, Taijasa. M - Deep sleep, Prajna. O - Turiya, the supreme Brahman beyond the highest. Nada - The collective Sutratma (thread-self). Bindu - The individual Hiranyagarbha (golden womb). Namaḥ - The gross Vishva. Shakti - The cosmic form. Śānti - The form of Viraj. All this is shown by the nine lines of omkara, thus: OM.

# Passage

ॐवृत्तस्य दशभुजं । वृत्तस्य पञ्च भुजंद्विर्बिभक्तं  । दशदिग्व्यापि ईश्वरात्माज्ञापकं  ।
      ॐन्नमः शक्तिःयुक्तं  । यथा अ, उ, ओ, म, ৺, ॰, नमः, शान्तिः, ।
               वा अ, उ, ओ, म, ৺, ॰, नमः शान्तिः, शान्तिः, शान्तिः ।

oṃvṛttasya daśabhujaṃ | vṛttasya pañca bhujaṃdvirbibhaktaṃ  | daśadigvyāpi īśvarātmājñāpakaṃ  |
      oṃnnamaḥ śaktiḥyuktaṃ  | yathā a, u, o, m, ৺, ॰, namaḥ, śāntiḥ, |
               vā a, u, o, m, ৺, ॰, namaḥ śāntiḥ, śāntiḥ, śāntiḥ |

The ten arms of the OM circle. The five arms of the circle divided twice. Indicating the Self of Ishvara pervading the ten directions. Combined with OM-namaḥ-śakti. Such as: A, U, O, M, nada, bindu, namaḥ, śānti; or A, U, O, M, nada, bindu, namaḥ, śānti, śānti, śānti.

प्रलीयन्ते तत्रवै ।

oṃmityevamagramāsīt | prathama moṅkārātmakamāsīt | tasmācca niḥsṛtāḥ sarbbe,
pralīyante tatravai |

Thus in the beginning was OM. First was that which had the nature of omkara. From that all emerged, and into that all dissolve.

Because of the principle of all-pervasiveness, it is thus called the bindu (point). The bindu has the form of anusvara (the nasal sound) and consists of consciousness. Thus says the Gayatri Tantra.

omityetadakṣaramidaṃ sarvvaṃ tasyopavyākhyānaṃ bhūtaṃ
bhaviṣyaditi sarvvamoṅkāra eva, yaccānyat trikālātītaṃ tadapyoṅkāra eva ||

OM—this imperishable syllable is all this. Its explanation is: the past, present, and future—all this is omkara alone. And whatever else transcends the three times, that too is omkara alone.

# Passage

तदेतदक्षरं ब्रह्मसप्राणस्तदबाङ्गनः ।तदेतत् सत्यं तदमृतं तद्वोद्धव्यं सौम्यबिद्धि ॥तदेतत् सर्ब्बाश्रयः आयम्य तद्भाब गतेन चेतसा ।लक्ष्यं तदेबाक्षरं सौम्य बिद्धि ॥तद्विज्ञानेन परिपश्यन्ति धीराः ।आनन्द रूपममृतं यद्बिभाति ॥तत् शुभ्रं तद् ज्योतिषां ज्योतिस्तदात्मबिदो बिदुः ।तमेवभान्तमनुभाति सर्ब्बं, तस्य भाषा सर्ब्बमिदम्बिभाति ॥

tadetadakṣaraṃ brahmasaprāṇastadavāṅganaḥ |tadetat satyaṃ tadamṛtaṃ tadvvoddhavyaṃ saumyaviddhi ||tadetat sarbbāśrayaḥ āyamya tadbhāva gatena cetasā |lakṣyaṃ tadevākṣaraṃ saumya viddhi ||tadvijñānena paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ |ānanda rūpamamṛtaṃ yadivibhāti ||tat śubhraṃ tad jyotiṣāṃ jyotistadātmavido viduḥ |tamevabhāntamanubhāti sarvvaṃ, tasya bhāṣā sarvvamidam vibhāti ||

That imperishable syllable is Brahman with prana, beyond speech and mind. That is truth, that is immortal, that is to be pierced—know this, O gentle one. That is the support of all; having drawn it in, with the mind absorbed in that state, know that imperishable target, O gentle one. The wise perceive it through knowledge. That which shines as the form of bliss and immortality. That is pure, that is the light of lights—the knowers of the Self know it. When that alone shines, all this shines after it; by its light, all this becomes luminous.

For those who are dispassionate, jnana yoga (the path of knowledge); for those still attached to actions here, karma yoga (the path of action); and for those whose minds are not yet dispassionate, karma yoga; and for the desirous, karma yoga as well.

तथा तत् प्रयोगकल्पः । प्राणायामः प्रत्याहारोध्यानंधारणातर्कः समाधिः । षड्वर्गो इत्युच्यते ।—    अनेन यदा पश्यन् पश्यति रुक्भवर्णं कर्त्तारमीशं पुरुषं ब्रह्मयोनिं ।
    तदाबिद्बान् पुण्य पापे विहाय परेऽव्यये सर्ब्ब​मेकी करोतीत्येबं ह्याह ।
    यथा पर्ब्बत​ मादीप्त माश्रयन्ति मृगद्विजाः । तद्वद्ब्रह्मविदो दोषानाश्रयन्ति कदाचन ॥१८    अथान्यत्राप्युक्तं । यदावैवहिर्विद्वान् मनोनियम्य इन्द्रियार्थांश्च प्राणोनिवेशयित्वा
    निःसङ्कल्पस्ततस्तिष्ठेत् । अप्राणादिह यस्मात् सम्भूतः प्राणसंज्ञको जीवस्तस्मात्
    प्राणोवैतुर्याख्ये धारयेत् । अचित्तं चित्तमध्यस्तमचिन्त्यं गुह्यमुत्तममं ।
    तत्र चित्तं निधायेत तच्च लिङ्गं निराश्रयं ॥

tathā tat prayogakalpaḥ | prāṇāyāmaḥ pratyāhārodhyānaṃdhāraṇātarkaḥ samādhiḥ | ṣaḍvargo ityucyate |—    anena yadā paśyan paśyati rukbhavarṇaṃ karttāramīśaṃ puruṣaṃ brahmayoniṃ |
    tadābidvān puṇya pāpe vihāya pare'vyaye sarvva​mekī karotītyevaṃ hyāha |
    yathā parvata​ madīpta māśrayanti mṛgadvijāḥ | tadvadbrahmavido doṣānāśrayanti kadācana ||18    athānyatrāpyuktaṃ | yadāvaivahirvidvān manoniyamya indriyārthāṃśca prāṇoniveśayitvā
    niḥsaṅkalpastatastiṣṭhet | aprāṇādiha yasmāt sambhūtaḥ prāṇasaṃjñako jīvastasmāt
    prāṇovaituryākhye dhārayet | acittaṃ cittamadhyastamacittyaṃ guhyamuttamamaṃ |
    tatra cittaṃ nidhāyeta tacca liṅgaṃ nirāśrayaṃ ||

Thus are the methods of practice. Pranayama (breath control), pratyahara (withdrawal of senses), dhyana (meditation), dharana (concentration), tarka (reasoning), and samadhi (absorption)—these are called the six limbs.

When through this one sees the golden-hued Creator, the Lord, the Purusha, the source of Brahman, then the knower, abandoning merit and sin, makes everything one in the supreme imperishable. Thus it is said: "As deer and birds take refuge in a burning mountain, so the knower of Brahman never takes refuge in defects." (18)

And it is also said elsewhere: When the wise one, having controlled the mind and the sense objects, and having established the prana (life-force), then stands free from concepts; because the jiva (individual soul) called prana is born from the breathless state, therefore one should hold the prana in that state called turiya (the fourth state). The mind is beyond mind, inconceivable, secret, and supreme. There one should place the mind, and that subtle mark is without support.

     śāntavirājarūpaṃ | sa​rvva​moṅkārasya nava rekhabhiḥ darśitaṃ | yathā oṃ

The nine arms of the OM circle. The three arms of the triangle divided into three sections. Combined with OM-namaḥ-śānti. A-U-O-M-nada-bindu-namaḥ-śānti. The nine forms of the Self, and likewise the nine doors of the living body. The nine forms of the Self are as follows: A - Waking state, Vaishvanara. U - Dream state, Taijasa. M - Deep sleep, Prajna. O - Turiya, the supreme Brahman beyond the highest. Nada - The collective Sutratma (thread-self). Bindu - The individual Hiranyagarbha (golden womb). Namaḥ - The gross Vishva. Shakti - The cosmic form. Śānti - The form of Viraj. All this is shown by the nine lines of omkara, thus: OM.

सदेवइदमग्र आसीत्, एकमेवाद्वितीयं ।तदाह एकेआहुः असदेवइदमग्रमासीत् एकमेवाद्वितीयं ॥तस्मादसतः सज्जायेत ।कुतस्तुखलु स्यादिति ।  कथमसतः सज्जायेत इति ॥तत्त्वेवइदमग्रआसीत्, एकमेवाद्वितीयं ॥तदैक्षत वहुस्यां प्रजायेय ।

saddevaidamagra āsīt, ekamevādvitīyaṃ |tadāha ekeāhuḥ asadevaidamagrамāsīt ekamevādvitīyaṃ ||tasmādasataḥ sajjāyeta |kutastukhalusu syāditi |  kathamasataḥ sajjāyeta iti ||tattvaevaidamagrāsīt, ekamevādvitīyaṃ ||tadaikṣata vahu syāṃ prajāyeya |

In the beginning, this was verily being (sat), one without a second. About this, some say: In the beginning, this was verily non-being (asat), one without a second. From that non-being, being would arise. But how could this be? How could being arise from non-being? Therefore, this was verily being in the beginning, one without a second. It thought: "May I become many, may I procreate."
